title.value: A protocol for trustworthy EEG decoding with neural networks
title.justification: The title succinctly describes the main focus of the paper, which is to develop a protocol for decoding EEG signals using neural networks.
title.quote: A protocol for trustworthy EEG decoding with neural networks

extractions.description: The paper presents a comprehensive protocol for decoding EEG signals using deep neural networks. It addresses the challenges of hyperparameter optimization and performance variability, providing solutions for a robust and trustworthy EEG decoding pipeline. The protocol is validated on multiple datasets and includes extensive experiments to explore the influence of various aspects such as participant numbers, search strategies, and random initializations.

type.justification: The paper conducts extensive experiments and validations on multiple datasets to test the proposed EEG decoding protocol.
type.quote: Our protocol is validated on 9 datasets about motor imagery, P300, SSVEP...and on different deep learning models.

name.justification: The primary focus of the study is on decoding EEG signals using neural networks.
name.quote: Deep learning solutions have rapidly emerged for EEG decoding, achieving state-of-the-art performance on a variety of decoding tasks.

name.justification: The study applies EEG decoding in the context of BCIs.
name.quote: Machine learning and deep learning approaches are widely used to process the brain activity...primarily by addressing classification tasks in Brain–Computer Interfaces (BCIs).

name.justification: EEGNet is specifically mentioned as the neural network architecture used for EEG decoding in the study.
name.quote: EEGNet (Lawhern et al., 2018) – in its original version (Lawhern et al., 2018) and its variants – represents the most used one.

is_contributed.justification: EEGNet is not a new contribution of this paper; it is referenced as a commonly used network for EEG.
is_contributed.quote: EEGNet (Lawhern et al., 2018) – in its original version (Lawhern et al., 2018) and its variants.

is_executed.justification: Experiments were conducted using EEGNet as part of the proposed protocol validation.
is_executed.quote: First, the network processes the input neural activity X i using temporal convolution, to learn how to optimally filter each EEG channel.

is_compared.justification: EEGNet is evaluated and compared with baseline protocols and possibly other models.
is_compared.quote: EEGNet-based protocol consistently outperformed baseline state-of-the-art protocols across datasets.

referenced_paper_title.value: EEGNet: a compact convolutional neural network for EEG-based brain–computer interfaces
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the original paper introducing EEGNet, as referenced in the document.
referenced_paper_title.quote: EEGNet (Lawhern et al., 2018) – in its original version...represents the most used one.

name.justification: The dataset is one of the publicly available MOABB datasets used for validation in the research.
name.quote: The dataset consists of 22-channel EEG recorded from 9 healthy participants across 2 recording sessions.

referenced_paper_title.value: Review of the BCI competition IV
referenced_paper_title.justification: BNCI2014-001 is part of the BCI Competition IV datasets, as mentioned in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This dataset is also known as ‘dataset IIa’ from BCI competition IV (Tangermann et al., 2012).

name.justification: The dataset is one of the publicly available datasets used for validating the protocol.
name.quote: The dataset consists of 16-channel EEG recorded from 10 healthy participants across 3 recording sessions.

referenced_paper_title.value: Influence of P300 latency jitter on event related potential-based brain–computer interface performance
referenced_paper_title.justification: This title refers to the dataset BNCI2014-009 as per the paper's description and references.

name.justification: The dataset is used as part of the evaluation on P300-based BCI paradigms.
name.quote: The dataset consists of 32-channel EEG recorded from 9 participants across 4 recording sessions.

referenced_paper_title.value: An efficient P300-based brain–computer interface for disabled subjects
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references this title for the EPFLP300 dataset that is used in their protocol validation.

name.justification: The library is explicitly mentioned as used for implementing the decoding protocol.
name.quote: The decoding protocol was implemented using the PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019)-based library.

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper by Paszke et al. is the foundational paper for the PyTorch library.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The decoding protocol was implemented using the PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019)-based library.
